practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase builds your basic vocabulary for describing data shapes so you can stop relying on the 'any' type in your code.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Refactoring existing small JavaScript functions into TypeScript by adding explicit parameter and return types.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Reading and interpreting compiler error messages in your IDE to understand type mismatches.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Annotating primitives like strings, numbers, and simple arrays.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Defining complex object shapes using interfaces and handling optional properties.

objective: Zero instances of explicit 'any' type in practice files
subjective: Increased comfort when reading TypeScript library documentation
Reduced anxiety when the compiler flags a type error

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase shifts your focus from static definitions to dynamic, reusable types which is the hallmark of intermediate proficiency.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Creating generic functions and classes that can operate on multiple types while maintaining safety.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Implementing built-in utility types like Partial or Record to transform existing interfaces.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Using union types to allow multiple specific values.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Writing generic constraints using the 'extends' keyword within type definitions.

objective: Successful implementation of a generic API wrapper or data transformer
Use of at least three different utility types in a project
subjective: Ability to predict how a type will flow through a generic function
Sense of control when configuring tsconfig.json strictness levels

objective: Compilation success rate on first attempt
Depth of type nesting handled without compiler errors
Ratio of inferred types vs explicit annotations in logic blocks
subjective: Perceived speed of bug resolution using type hints
Confidence in refactoring internal logic without breaking external contracts
Ease of navigating new TypeScript-based codebases

architect_notes: Your 3-hour weekly window is tight; prioritize consistency over session length (e.g., 3 sessions of 1 hour).
Avoid 'any' at all costs to ensure you are actually practicing the type system's logic.
The duration of Cycle 2 is doubled to account for the steep conceptual climb of generics at your current time commitment.

details.reason: User initiated a new learning session.

timeline.title: Initial Practice Strategy Created
timeline.summary: Initial practice strategy created for ['Learn Typescript'].

details.reason: Sufficient information provided to create initial practice system.

constraints.dropout_risk: frustration with strict compiler rules during low-hour weeks

inferred_fields: learning_style (inferred from common technical skill acquisition)
dropout_risk (inferred from time constraints and language strictness)
